title: 108_hr1874
content: The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" clarifies the definition of homebound through a demonstration project. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" establishes a demonstration project for Medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions to receive home health services. Beneficiaries are deemed homebound if they have a permanent and severe condition, require assistance with daily activities, and need home health services. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" sets up a Medicare demonstration project for beneficiaries with chronic conditions. They must be homebound, needing assistance with daily activities and home health services. The Secretary will collect data on the project's quality of care, patient outcomes, and costs to Medicare. A report to Congress is due one year after the project's implementation. The Secretary will submit reports to Congress on the Medicare demonstration project one year after implementation, using data collected on patient outcomes and costs. Waiver authority allows flexibility in complying with Social Security Act requirements for conducting demonstration projects. The Secretary has the authority to conduct demonstration projects under the Social Security Act, with the ability to waive penalties for false certifications. Appropriations from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Insurance Trust Fund are authorized for project costs. Definitions are provided in this section. The Secretary can conduct demonstration projects under the Social Security Act, waiving penalties for false certifications. Appropriations from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Insurance Trust Fund are authorized for project costs. Definitions for terms like "Medicare beneficiary," "home health services," and "activities of daily living" are provided in this section. The definition of homebound for determining eligibility for home health services under the Medicare program is clarified. The definition of homebound for eligibility for Medicare home health services is clarified for individuals with permanent and severe conditions requiring assistance with daily living activities. The Secretary may not disqualify individuals needing assistance to leave their home from being considered 'confined to his home' for Medicare eligibility. A report on a demonstration project's impact on home health services under Medicare must be submitted by the Secretary by December 1, 2006. The project established under section 2 analyzes the effect of a demonstration project on home health services under the Medicare program. The project will be discontinued on January 1, 2007, unless the Secretary finds that the clarification of the definition of homebound negatively impacts home health services or causes an unreasonable increase in Medicare expenditures. If such a finding is made, it will be included in the report. The Secretary will include specific data and recommendations in the report if a finding is made that the clarification of the definition of homebound negatively impacts home health services or causes an unreasonable increase in Medicare expenditures. The text chunk discusses recommendations to exempt severely disabled homebound beneficiaries from restrictions on absences to qualify for home health services without additional costs to the Medicare program. Technical amendments are made to sections of the Social Security Act to reflect these changes.
